question: standing in front of a shelf of cubbyholes. As we FOLLOW his hand drawing an 8 X 10 envelope across the line of alphabetized mail slots. The envelope is addressed to Max Kloppitt, Jr. ...Bring it down to fif ... fifteen... sign the voucher, uh, waiver... cover for Mr. Anatole... he's a swell guy... Morgatross... He was on, uh... He raises his voice over the mailroom din: Say, what do you do when the envelope is too big for the slot?
answer: Well... if ya fold 'em, they fire ya... ...I usually throw 'em out.

question: Just got hired today!
answer: Terrific.

question: Ya know, entry level!
answer: Tell me about it.

question: I got big ideas, though!
answer: I'm sure you do.

question: For instance, take a look at this sweet baby... ...you look like you can keep a secret... ...Something I developed myself. Yessir, this is my ticket upstairs. ...You know, for kids!
answer: Terrific.

question: So ya see, I won't be in the mailroom long.
answer: Nooo, I don't guess you will be.

question: How long've you been down here?
answer: Forty-eight years... ...Next year they move me up to parcels... ...If I'm lucky. Jumpin' Jehosephat, a blue letter!

question: Hiya, buddy! The name is Buzz, I got the fuzz... ...I make the elevator do what she duzz! ...Hang it up to dry. ...What's your pleasure, buddy?
answer: Forty-fourth floor, and it's very --

question: Forty-four, the top brass floor say, buddy! What takes fifty years to get up to the top floor and thirty seconds to get down? Waring Hudsucker! Na-ha-ha-ha-ha! Say, buddy! Mr. Kline, up to nine. Mrs. Dell, personnel. Mr. Levin, thirty-seven. Walk down. Ladies and gentlemen, step to the rear; here comes gargantuan Mr. Grier. Say, buddy! Who's the most liquid businessman on the street?
answer: Well, I --

question: Waring Hudsucker! Na-ha-ha-ha-ha! Say, buddy! When is the sidewalk fully dressed? When it's 'wearing' Hudsucker! Na-ha-ha-ha! ...Ya get it, buddy, it's a pun, it's a knee-slapper, it's a play on Jesus, Joseph and Mary, is that a blue letter?! ...Cripes a'mighty, whyn't ya tell a guy?! Hold on, folks, we're express to the top floor! Good luck, buddy! -- You'll need it!
answer: ...Mr. Mussburger's office? Uhh, no, I -- No, ma'am, ya see, I wouldn't be in the -- No, ma'am, ya see I don't have an -- I know but ya see I have this -- here it is, this letter --

question: I'll be right there. Give him a magazine. ...What're you, a mute? ...Yeah, how's the stock doing? ...Bad, huh? Well it's not bad enough. ...Look, chump, either you find me a grade A ding-dong or you can tender your key to the executive washroom. And that goes double for you. Ear-clay? Ood-gay! This better be good. I'm in a bad mood.
answer: Well, sir. I've got something for you from the mailroom, but first if I could just take a minute or so from your very busy time... ...to show you a, uh... ...a little something I've been working on for the last two or three years... ...You know, for kids! Which is perfect for Hudsucker -- not that I claim to be any great genius; like they say, inspiration is 99 percent perspiration, and in my case I'd say it's at least twice that, but I gotta tell ya, Mr. Mussburger, sir, this sweet baby --

question: Wait a minute! Hmmm... Umm-hmm... Siddown. ...Go ahead. Try it on. ...Put your feet up. ...Go ahead. Hmmmm... Let's get to know one another, shall we? ...Let's chat! ...Man to man! ...You weren't blessed with much... ...education, were you?
answer: Well, I'm a college graduate --

question: All right, but you didn't excel in your studies...?
answer: Well, I made the dean's list.

question: Hmmm.
answer: At the Muncie College of Business Administration.

question: Sure, sure. And did your classmates there call you 'jerk' or... ...'schmoe'? ...'Shnook'? 'Dope'? 'Dipstick'? 'Lamebrain'?
answer: No, sir.

question: Not even behind your back?
answer: Sir! They voted me most likely to succeed!

question: You're fired.
answer: But, sir! --

question: Get your feet off that desk.
answer: But --

question: Get out of my sight. My God! The Bumstead contracts!!
answer: Oh my God, sir!

question: You nitwit! I worked for three years on this deal!
answer: Oh my God, sir!

question: I'll take care of it. Just get out! Why you nitwit. You almost destroyed the most sensitive deal of my career!
answer: Oh my God, sir!

question: Now out of here! Out! Not that way! Through the door!
answer: But, sir!

question: Right away, buster! Out of my office! Up on your feet! We don't crawl at Hudsucker Industries!
answer: Sir, my leg is on fire!

question: Get out of this office, you dithering nincompoop!
answer: Oh my God, sir!

question: My God! The Bumstead contracts!
answer: Oh my God, sir!

question: Eeeeeeaaaahhhhh!
answer: Desperately hanging onto Mussburger by his legs. Don't worry, Mr. Mussburger! I gotcha. I gotcha by your pants!

question: is in a basement tailor shop. LUIGI, an old Italian tailor, is just running his tape up Mussburger's inseam. No! Single stitch is fine. Why on earth would I need a double stitch? To pad your bill? Single stitch is fine! Damn! sighs with relief.
answer: Norville's arms are wrapped around Mussburger's ankles; the heels of Mussburger's shoes are digging into his face.

question: Looking. Thinking.
answer: Struggling to hold on.

question: Calm. Contemplating. Hmmm...
answer: His face drawn with effort, still struggling to hang on.

question: 'The Einstein of Enterprise.' 'The Edison of Industry.' 'The Billion- Dollar Cranium'... 'Idea Man'! And not one of you mugs has given me a story on him!! Facts, figures, charts! They never sold a newspaper! I read this morning's edition of the Argus and let me tell you something Suuuure, Tibbs, take a break! Go to Florida! Lie in the sun! Wait for a coconut to drop, file a story on it -- it'll be more of a grabber than your piece on the commie grain surplus! The human angle! That's what sells papers! We need a front page with heart and the whole idea of the 'Idea Man' idea can put it there! Yeah, and if a frog had wings he wouldn't bump his ass a-hoppin'! I don't want excuses, I want results! I wanna know what makes the Idea Man tick! Where is he from? Where is he going? I wanna know everything about this guy! Has he got a girl? Has he got parents? All right, how many? How 'bout it, Parkinson, you've been awful quiet over there. The only thing that runs deep with Parkinson is the holes in his ears. Yes, the Idea Man! What're his hopes and dreams, his desires and aspirations? Does he think all the time or does he set aside a certain portion of the day? How tall is he and what's his shoe size? Where does he sleep and what does he eat for breakfast? Does he put jam on his toast or doesn't he put jam on his toast, and if not why not and since when? ...Well?!! ...Ahh, you're useless. Yes, Idea Man! Creator! Innovator! Cerebrator! Tycoon!-- Huhh!!
answer: I tell ya the guy's a phony.

question: Phony, huh?
answer: As a three-dollar bill.

question: Sez who?
answer: Sez me! Amy Archer. Why is he an Idea Man -- because Hudsucker says he is? What're his ideas? Why won't they let anyone interview him?... ...And just take a look at the mug on this guy -- the jutting eyebrows, the simian forehead, the idiotic grin. Why he has a face only a mother could love -- ...On payday! The only story here is how this guy made a monkey out of you, Al.

question: Yeah, well, monkey or not I'm still editor of this rag. Amy, I thought you were doing that piece on the F.B.I. -- J. Edgar Hoover
answer: I filed it yesterday.

question: Well, do a follow-up
answer: Al, he's the bunk. I'll stake my Pulitzer on it!

question: Say, Mr. Muss -- uh, Sid! Shouldn't we be a little bit concerned with the downward spiral of our stock these last few days? I mean, you're the expert, but at the Muncie College of Business Administration they told us --
answer: Relax, Norville. It's only natural in a period of transition for the more nervous element to run for cover.

question: Okay, Sid. Like I said, you're the expert, but -- ...You don't happen to remember the plan I outlined to you the day I set fire to your off -- uh, the day I was promoted?
answer: I do remember and I was impressed. Anyway, that's all forgotten now. Driver!

question: Thank you, Sid, but the reason I mention it is, it would require such a small capital investment -- again, you're the expert here --
answer: Damnit, where's my car!

question: -- But there's such an enormous potential profit-wise given the demographics -- baby boom -- discretionary income in the burgeoning middle class --
answer: Finally.

question: -- So if you think it's appropriate, I'd like to bounce the idea off a few people at lunch --
answer: Sure, sure, tell whoever you want... ...And I'd like to hear more about it at some point, too.

question: I'm sorry we had to take the stairs. It was just that horrible little elevator boy...
answer: Not at all. You're light as a feather.

question: The couch, please.
answer: Just a minute.

question: I don't know what came over me. I suppose it was the shock of eating after so long without; the enzymes kicking in after so long, or whatever. But then you couldn't possibly know what it is to be tired and hungry...
answer: Hungry, anyway.

question: I don't want to bore you with all the sordid details of my life; it's not a happy story... ...Suffice it to say that I'm jobless -- though not for want of trying, that I'm friendless, with no one to -- thank you -- take care of me; and that had you not come along at just exactly the moment that you did -- Norville, I didn't know you were president here!
answer: Oh, it's nothing really. Just determination and hard work... ...Of course, when I started in the mailroom last Tuesday I thought it might take more time --

question: What a horrible little person.
answer: Oh, Buzz is pretty harmless, really --

question: At any rate I arrived in town not ten days ago, full of dreams and aspirations, anxious to make my way in the world -- A little naive perhaps but -- thank you -- armed with determination, a solid work ethic, and an indomitable belief in the future --
answer: I myself --

question: Only to have that belief, that unsullied optimism, dashed against the marble and mortar of the modern work place --
answer: Cigarette?

question: No thank you. Seek and ye shall find, work and ye shall prosper -- these were the watch words of my education, the ethics of my tender years -- -- these were the values that were instilled in me while I was growing up in a little town you've probably never heard of --
answer: Mind if I join you?

question: He waves his arms and talks with a thick rasp as he staggers to his feet. Excuse me -- I -- executive washroom...
answer: Are you all right?... ...Is it your lunch? The chicken a la king?

question: No, I --
answer: Is the a la king repeating on you?

question: ...I'm fine, I... You were saying?
answer: Values... watchwords... uh, tender years... -- A little town you've probably never heard of... ...Muncie, Indiana.

question: You're from Muncie?!
answer: Why yes, do you know it?

question: 'Fight on fight on dear old Muncie Fight on -- Hoist the gold and blue You'll be tattered, torn and hurtin' Once 'The Munce' is done with you!' ...Goooooooo Eagles! ...A Muncie girl! Talk about the cat's pyjamas! Tell you what, Amy. I'm gonna cancel the rest of my appointments this afternoon and get you a job here at the Hud.
answer: Oh, no, really, I --

question: Don't bother to thank me, it's the easiest thing in the world. Matter of fact, I know where a vacancy just came up. ...Mail room. ...This'll only take a moment. Good afternoon to ya, this is Norville Barnes -- ...Well, I'm not sure where I -- But look, I'm president of the company now and I -- Oh, of all the foolish... Listen, do you take shorthand? Are you familiar with the mimeograph machine?
answer: Of course -- I went to the Muncie, uh, Secretarial Polytechnic!

question: -- A Muncie girl! Can you beat that!
answer: Well, I just don't know how to thank you, Mr. Barnes --

question: Please! Norville! ...It's my pleasure! ...Gooooooo Eagles!
answer: likewise hooks her thumbs in front of her nose, makes wings, and, winking back: Gooooooooo Eagles!

question: likewise hooks her thumbs in front of her nose, makes wings, and, winking back: Gooooooooo Eagles!
answer: ...Once 'The Munce'... Holy...

question: And is this guy from chumpsville?! I pulled the old mother routine --
answer: Adenoids?

question: Lumbago.
answer: That gag's got whiskers on it!

question: I'm telling you, Smitty, the board of Hudsucker is up to something --
answer: Yeah.

question: -- And it's a cinch -- Goiter -- it's a cinch this guy isn't in on it. How much time to make the Late Final?
answer: Chief.

question: Hiya, Chief, just the person I wanted to apologize to...
answer: About seven minutes.

question: Yeah, I was all wet about your idea man... Well, thanks for being so generous... It is human, and you are divine... No, he's no faker. He's the 100% real McCoy beware-of- imitations genuine article -- as in a five-letter word for imbecile -- -- as pure a specimen as I've ever run across... Am I sure he's a nitwit? Heck, if working at the Argus doesn't make me an expert then my name isn't Amy Archer and I've never won the Pulitzer Prize... ...In 1957... My series on the reunited triplets -- come on down here, hammerhead, and I'll show it to ya... Not now, Morris, I'm busy -- That's right, I said hammerhead, as in a ten-letter word for a smug bullying self-important newspaperman -- -- Gnu -- -- who couldn't find -- -- That's G-N-U -- -- couldn't find the Empire State Building with a compass, a road map and a native guide. -- or emu. ...And that's just the potatoes, Smitty, here comes the gravy
answer: Better off falling for a rattlesnake.

question: I'm tellin' ya, this guy's just the patsy and I'm gonna find out what for. There's a real story, Smitty, some kind of plot, a setup, a cabal, a -- oh, and say, did I tell ya?!
answer: He didn't offer you money.

question: A sawbuck!
answer: Ten dollars? Let's grab a highball!

question: On Norville Barnes! ...Copy!
answer: Miss Smith, can you come in please to take a letter... ...of all the cockamamie... ...Did you happen to see the front page of today's Manhattan Argus?

question: Well, I... didn't bother to read the article. I didn't think the picture did you justice.
answer: The picture was fine! It's what that knuckle-headed dame wrote underneath! Of all the irresponsible... Amy, take this down

question: -- or lack thereof?
answer: -- these preposterous inventions, would be better suited to the pages of Amazing Tales Magazine. If the editors of the Manhattan Argus see fit to publish the rantings of a disordered mind, perhaps they will see fit to publish this letter! But I doubt it. I most seriously doubt it. As I doubt also that you could find a home at Amazing Tales, a periodical which I have enjoyed for many years. Yours sincerely, et cetera.

question: Is that all, Mr. Barnes?
answer: ...Well, you know me, Amy, at least better than that that dame does. Do you think I'm an imbecile?

question: I'm sure I --
answer: Go on, tell the truth; I trust you and I put a lot of stock in your opinion.

question: Well, I --
answer: Oh sure, you're biased -- you're a fellow Muncian. But would an imbecile come up with this? ...I designed it myself and this is just the sweet baby that can put Hudsucker right back on top. ...You know! For kids!

question: ...Why don't I just type this up...
answer: Aww, naw, Amy, that won't be necessary. I shouldn't send it; she's just doing her job, I guess.

question: Well, I don't know; maybe she does deserve it. Maybe she should've come in to face you man to man.
answer: Well, she probably had a deadline...

question: Sure, but -- she could still have gotten your side for the record!
answer: Well, it's done now -- what's the use of grousing about it. Forget the letter, Amy, I just had to blow off some steam... ...She's probably just a little confused.

question: Confused?
answer: Yeah, you know, probably one of these fast-talking career gals, thinks she's one of the boys. Probably is one of the boys, if you know what I mean.

question: I'm quite sure I don't know what you mean.
answer: Yeah, you know. Suffers from one of these complexes they have nowadays. Seems pretty obvious, doesn't it? She's probably very unattractive and bitter about it.

question: Oh, is that it!
answer: Yeah, you know. Probably dresses in men's clothing, swaps drinks with the guys at the local watering hole, and hobnobs with some smooth talking heel in the newsroom named Biff or Smoocher or...

question: Smitty.
answer: Exactly. And I bet she's ugly. Real ugly. Otherwise, why wouldn't they print her picture next to her byline?

question: Maybe she puts her work ahead of her personal appearance.
answer: I bet that's exactly what she tells herself! But you and I both know she's just a dried-up bitter old maid. Say, how about you and I grab a little dinner and a show after work? I was thinking maybe The King and I -- ...How about Oklahoma?

question: Norville Barnes, you don't know a thing about that woman! You don't know who she really is! And only a numbskull thinks he knows things about things he knows nothing about!
answer: Say, what gives?

question: Huh?! Who are you? How did you know who I am?
answer: Ah guess ole Moses knows jes about ever'thing, leastways if it concerns Hudsuckuh.

question: But -- who are you -- what d'you do here?
answer: Ah keeps the ol' circle turning -- this ol' clock needs plenty o' care. Time is money, Miss Archuh, and money -- it drives that ol' global economy and keeps big Daddy Earth a-spinnin' on 'roun'. Ya see, without that capital fo'mation --

question: Yeah, yeah. Say, you won't tell anyone about me, will you?
answer: I don't tell no one nothin' lessen they ask. Thatches ain't ole Moses' way.

question: So if you know everything about Hudsucker, tell me why the Board decided to make Norville Barnes president.
answer: Well, that even surprised ole Moses at fust. I didn't think the Board was that smart.

question: That smart?!
answer: But then I figured it out

question: Why on earth would they want a nitwit to be president?
answer: 'Cause they's little pigglies! They's tryin' to inspire panic, make that stock git cheap so's they can snitch it all up fo' themselves! But Norville, he's got some tricks up his sleeve, he does... ...you know, fo' kids? Yeah, he's a smart one, that Norville, heh-heh, he's a caution. Wal, some folks is square, an' some is hip -- ...But I guess you don't really know him any better than that board does, do ya, Miss Archuh?

question: Well, maybe I --
answer: An' only some kind a knucklehead thinks she knows things 'bout things she, uh -- when she don't, uh -- How'd that go?

question: It's hardly the same --
answer: Why you don't even know y'own self -- you ain't exactly the genuine article are you, Miss Archuh?

question: Well, in connection with my job, sometimes I have to go undercover as it were --
answer: I don't mean that! Why you pretendin' to be such a hard ol' sourpuss! Ain't never gonna make you happy! Never made Warin' happy.

question: I'm happy enough.
answer: Okay, Miss Archuh. ...I got gears to see to.

question: I'm plenty happy!
answer: Elsewhere in the great room, he is hunkered down next to a catchment which he buffs with a greasy rag. Amy's VOICE ECHOES UP:

question: ...Hello?
answer: Them po' young folks. Looks like Norville's in fo' the same kind o' heartache ol' Warin' had. But then, she never axed me 'bout dat...

question: All right, I was out of line. But you're out of line with this stock swindle story. Gimme some more of that Moron-from-Sheboygan stuff --
answer: Muncie.

question: Whatever. That's what sells newspapers.
answer: I've got an even hotter story -- The Sap from the City Desk.

question: Watch it, Archer --
answer: It's about a dimwitted editor who --

question: -- So we'd gone out to the Hamptons and the garden was in positive ruins!
answer: That must have been quite a disappointment, Mrs. Mussburger.

question: Disappointment? J'etais destroyee! I was in bed for a week! Positively sick with fury! I called in the gardener and said, 'Monsieur Gonzalez, either those azaleas come up next spring or you are terminee! I'm brushing up on my French with the most charming man, Pierre of Fifth Avenue. Do you know him?
answer: I haven't had --

question: You have a charming wife, Mr. Muss -- uh, Sid.
answer: So they tell me. Norville, let me shepherd you through some of the introductions here. Try not to talk too much; some of our biggest stockholders are, uh -- scratch that

question: As Mussburger introduces him to a tall, imposing BUSINESSMAN in a tuxedo and a ten-gallon hat.
answer: Norville Barnes, allow me to introduce Mr. Zebulon Cardozo, one of Hudsucker Industries largest and most loyal stockholders.

question: No need for concern, sir; it's only natural in a period of transition for the more timid element to run for cover -- I'm sorry, Sid, I thought maybe if I showed him the long view we might --
answer: Norville, this is Thorstensen Finlandsen, who heads a radical splinter group of disgruntled investors.

question: Hello, Mr. Finlandsen, so sorry to meet you -- uh, happy to walk into y -- uh, pleased to make your -- Thank you, sir... ...I understand your concern about the down-ward, you know, but I think you'll find under our strong new leadership... We anticipate, in short order, an upward...
answer: Bad.

question: ...Norville? ...What happened?
answer: Oh. Nothing, really, just... the more timid investors are no longer running for cover.

question: Let me look.
answer: Sid found me the icepack.

question: Let me hold it, or you'll have a real shiner.
answer: Thanks. People seem to be pretty hot over this imbecile story.

question: ...I'm sorry.
answer: Oh, it isn't your fault, Amy. You're the one person who's been standing by me through all this.

question: Norville... there's something I have to tell you. You see, I'm not really a secretary.
answer: I know that, Amy.

question: ...You do?
answer: I understand that you're not very skilled yet in the secretarial arts. I'm not that skilled as president. Oh sure, I put up a big front -- -- not that everyone's buying it.

question: I believe in you, Norville -- At least I believe in your... intentions --
answer: Oh, I don't blame them, really. I guess I have sort of made a mess of things. These folks have to protect their investment. Most of them are very nice people --

question: Norville, you can't trust people here like you did in Muncie... ...Certain people are --
answer: Didja ever go to the top of old man Larson's feed tower and look out over the town?

question: ...Huh?
answer: You know, on farm route 17.

question: Oh yes! In Muncie!
answer: No! In Vidalia! Farm Route 17!

question: Uh -- Yes. Seventeen. Yes, I -- well no, I -- I never really... There's a place I go now, the cutest little place near my apartment in Greenwich Village. It's called Ann's 440. It's a beatnik bar.
answer: You don't say.

question: Yes, you can get carrot juice or Italian coffee, and the people there -- well, none of them quite fit in. You'd love it -- why don't you come there with me -- they're having a marathon poetry reading on New Year's Eve. I go every year.
answer: Every year?

question: Well -- this year -- if it's good I plan to make it a tradition. Uh, my it certainly is beautiful -- ...The people look like ants.
answer: Well, the Hindus say -- and the beatniks also -- that in the next life some of us will come back as ants. Some will be butterflies. Others will be elephants or creatures of the sea.

question: What a beautiful thought.
answer: What do you think you were in your previous life, Amy?

question: Oh, I don't know. Maybe I was just a fast-talking career gal who thought she was one of the boys --
answer: Oh no, Amy, pardon me for saying so but I find that very farfetched.

question: Norville, there really is something I have to tell you --
answer: That kind of person would come back as a wildebeest, or a warthog. No, I think it more likely that you were a gazelle, with long, graceful legs, gamboling through the underbrush. Perhaps we met once, a chance encounter in a forest glade. I must have been an antelope or an ibex. What times we must have had -- foraging together for sustenance, picking the grubs and burrs from one another's coats. Or perhaps we simply touched our horns briefly and went our separate ways...

question: I wish it were that simple, Norville. I wish I was still a gazelle, and you were an antelope or an ibex.
answer: Well, can I at least call you deer? Ha-ha-ha-ha-ha! Seriously, Amy, the whole thing is what your beatnik friends call 'karma' -- the great circle of life, death and rebirth.

question: Yeah, I think I've heard of that. What goes around comes around.
answer: That's it. A great wheel that gives us each what we deserve... ...Tomorrow's my big presentation to the board. I've gotta show Sidney and the guys that I deserve all their confidence!

question: Oh, Norville --
answer: Kiss me once, Amy! Kiss me once for luck!

question: Sure, Norville, sure... ...Oh, Norville!
answer: -- So we have economy, simplicity, low production cost and the potential for mass appeal, and all that spells out great profitability... ...I had the boys down at R & D throw together this prototype so that our discussion here could have some focus... ...and to give you gentlemen of the Board a first-hand look at just how exciting this gizmo is... ...It's fun, it's healthy, it's good exercise; kids'll just love it, and we put a little sand inside to make the whole experience more pleasant. And the great part is we won't have to charge an arm and a leg!

question: Does it have rules?
answer: Can more than one play? Is it a game?

question: Is there an object?
answer: Are you supposed to make it fly off? How can you tell when you're done?

question: How do you make it stop?
answer: Can a parent assemble it??

question: Rockwell News presents... 'Tidbits of Time!' World news in pictures, we kid you not.
answer: Picture dissolves to a pan up the Hudsucker Building.

question: ...What began as the brainchild of this Madison Avenue whiz kid is now a craze sweeping the nation. The 'hula hoop,' product of Hudsucker Industries, is a recreational device that some experts predict may eclipse the television as a means of entertainment...
answer: A television sits against a neutral b.g. A hula hoop rolls into frame and bumps the TV, pushing it out of frame.

question: ...This dancing dingus of delight, this jerky circle of gaiety, is proving to be the toy of choice of most American youngsters. -- Whoa- ho! Did I say youngsters?! Here's mom, taking a break from her household chores...
answer: A woman switches off her vacuum cleaner, takes a hula hoop that is conveniently leaning against a nearby wall, and starts hula hooping.

question: ...and even dad is 'swinging' into the act!
answer: In the office, dad, smoking a pipe, is also hula hooping.

question: ...and so the congratulations pour in for up-and-comer Norville Barnes, inventor of the hoop -- including one very special call!
answer: In jerky cinema-verite footage, a woman is excitedly sticking her head in Norville's door.

question: Yes, it's hula hula everywhere! From the cocktail parties of the Park Avenue smart set...
answer: A group of people in formal evening wear are sipping highballs and chatting as they keep hoops in motion 'round their waists.

question: ...to sweethearts who want to be married in the 'swing' of things...
answer: A young couple stands before the altar hula hooping.

question: ...To our friend the Negro, in the heart of the dark continent.
answer: Pan down from elephant to two natives hula hooping as they grin into the newsreel camera. The mean laugh. Yes, as we draw closer, it seems clear that his laugh is colder than before.

question: Pull yourself together, Addison.
answer: Nobody told me! Nobody told me! You sold all of our stock?

question: We dumped the whole load. Now quit showboating, Addison --
answer: I had twenty thousand shares! I'd be a millionaire now!

question: Sure, sure, we'd all be millionaires. There's no point in looking back. At the time, Stilson thought dumping our position would panic the market, further depress the stock -- then we'd buy it all back, and more of course, once it got cheap --
answer: Cheap! Cheap! It's never been more valuable! And I'm ruined! Ruined! I'm getting off this merry-go-round!

question: Hold it!... ...Nobody move, nobody breathe... ...An idea... is coming... Deflates. He glares at the tailor. It's gone now. Is she in the book? --
answer: For Pete's sake, Norville!

question: Oh! Hello, Amy -- was it -- I thought she said, Mamie --
answer: Never mind about that... ...You know what those nincompoops in the boardroom are doing?

question: Well, I wouldn't call them nincom --
answer: They're going to discharge eight percent of the work force here at Hudsucker. Why, in New York alone that means eighteen hundred people out of work, people with wives and children and families --

question: Well yes, we're pruning away some of the dead wood, but if --
answer: You mean you know about this?

question: Know about it? You think the Board would do anything like this without my authorization? No, this was my idea from the start.
answer: Your i --

question: We have to be realistic, Amy. You know things have slowed down a little here at Hudsucker --
answer: You're awful kind to yourself, Norville Barnes -- the fact is you've slowed down, sitting up here like a sultan, not doing a lick of work! Why you know it's ideas that are the lifeblood of industry and you haven't come up with one since the hoop and the reason's plain to see! You've forgotten what made your ideas exciting for you in the first place -- it wasn't for the fame and the wealth and the mindless adulation of -- would you get out of here?! ...I've been watching you, Norville Barnes, even though you've been trying to avoid me --

question: Now, Aim --
answer: Shutup! -- and don't think I haven't noticed how you've changed. I used to think you were a swell guy -- well, to be honest I thought you were an imbecile --

question: Now, Aim --
answer: Shutup! -- but then I figured out you were a swell guy, a little slow maybe, but a swell guy! Well, maybe you're not so slow, but you're not so swell either and it looks like you're an imbecile after --

question: Now, Aim --
answer: Shutup! -- after all! You haven't talked to me for a week and now I'm going to say my piece. I've got a prediction for you, Norville Barnes

question: Worked in a watch factory?
answer: Shutup! Exactly! Don't you remember how you used to feel about the hoop? You told me you were gonna bring a smile to the hips of everyone in America, regardless of race, creed or color. Finally there'd be a thingamajig that would bring everyone together -- even if it kept 'em apart, spacially -- you know, for kids? Your words, Norville, not mine. I used to love Norville Barnes -- yes, love him! -- when he was just a swell kid with hot ideas who was in over his head, but now your head is too big to be in over!

question: Now, Amy --
answer: Consider this my resignation -- -- Effective immediately!!

question: Huh-whuh?
answer: Looks like ya nodded off there, buddy! Say, ya got a minute?

question: Oh, uh... Buzz... Is it important?
answer: I like to think so! It's this little idea I been working on! ...Ya see, I don't intend to be an elevator boy forever! Take a look at this sweet baby! ...Ya get it, buddy? Incredibly convenient, isn't it? Ya see -- -- this is how it works, it's these little ridges on the side that give it its whammy! See, ya don't have to drink like this anymore -- -- Now you can drink like this -- ...I call it the Buzz-Sucker, get it, buddy? -- After me! Buzz! Why, people are just dyin' for a product like this, and the great thing is we won't have to charge an arm and a --

question: Wait a minute! ...Why, this is worthless.
answer: Huh?! But, buddy --

question: This is the most idiotic thing I've ever seen in my life!
answer: Yeah, but, buddy --

question: Nobody wants a hare-brained product like this! Ya see, Buzz, it lacks the creative spark, the unalloyed genius that made, uh... ...say, the hula hoop such a success.
answer: But, buddy --

question: And what do you mean barging in here and taking up my valuable time! I've got a company to run here --
answer: But, buddy, you were --

question: -- I can't have every deadbeat on the Hudsucker payroll pestering me with their idiotic brainwaves!
answer: Geez, I'm sorry, buddy --

question: An example must be made!
answer: Wuddya mean, buddy?

question: Fired! You're fired! Is that plain enough for you, buster!
answer: Awwww, buddy --

question: And don't call me buddy! Out of here! Out!
answer: Aw, please, sir -- this job, it's all I got!

question: Get up!
answer: I understand if ya don't like the Buzz-Sucker! Just lemme keep my job, I'm prayin' to ya!

question: We don't crawl at Hudsucker Industries! Get out of my office! Leave your uniform in the locker room!
answer: I'm sorry, buddy... I'm sorry...

question: Buzz... off! Ha-ha-ha-ha! Sorry I'm late, Sid. That back nine at Riverdale is really murder.
answer: Sure, sure, it's a tough course. Well thanks for coming, kid. I thought the board room would be a swell place to chat undisturbed -- it seems we're having some security problems here at the Hud.

question: Ya don't say.
answer: Mm. Ordinarily I wouldn't bother you with it, but -- this is embarrassing, kid -- it seems to concern you directly.

question: How's that, Sid?
answer: It's not important in itself -- some elevator boy you fired came to me claiming you'd stolen the idea for the, uh, the hoop dingus from him --

question: Huh?! He -- no, I -- he's just -- maybe I was a little rough on the boy, ya see I --
answer: Ah forget it, kid, ya don't have to explain to me. He's a little person. He's nothing. Like I say, ordinarily it would just be a nuisance. But it seems -- well, there was a spy in the company... ...Sure, sure, we tried to kill the story. But her newspaper won't play ball... Looks like her story's coming out... ...See, kid, the problem the Board'll have... you hired this woman. Kept her on, while she made a chump out of you. Serious error of judgment... I mean, business is war, kid -- ya take no prisoners, ya get no second chances. And a boner like this... I'm afraid when the Board meets, after New Year's, your position... well, it looks like you're finished... stick a fork in ya, you're done... washed up... ...I'm sorry, kid. I understand this dolly who betrayed you, she used to be a friend of yours... ...And this elevator dope used to be a friend, too... ...Well, they've got your throat pretty well slit. And when you're dead, ya stay dead. Ya don't believe me, ask Waring Hudsucker... Yeah, looks like curtains. Well, condolences, kid...

question: Muncie!
answer: Whatever! It's no dig on you, Archer, but this story is hot and you're no longer on top of it. Why, it's the scoop of the century -- the other papers won't have the Gunderson dope 'til tomorrow -- The Allemeinischer Zeitung, Le Figaro, they'll be choking on our dust come mornin' --

question: You're fools, both of you! It's obvious they're out to crucify Norville! They're trying to destroy him!
answer: Amy -- take a break. You've worked hard on this story -- heck, you broke it for us! But it's passed you by and Smith here has taken up the slack.

question: Yeah, just get down here -- he says he's a friend of yours... He won't say, but man, is he from squaresville.
answer: I want a martini! It's New Year's Eve and I want a Martini!

question: Daddy, it's like I been tellin' ya --
answer: I thought you served misfits here!

question: Yeah, daddy, that's a roger, but we don't sell alcohol.
answer: What kind of bar is it if ya can't get a martini?!

question: It's a juice and coffee bar, man, like I been tellin' ya --
answer: I want a martini! On this bar, right now! I've had a martini in every bar on the way down here, and I'm not about to --

question: Martinis are for squares, man.
answer: What'd you call me?! ...You son of a --

question: What'd you call me?! ...You son of a --
answer: Norville!

question: Huh?! ...Oh, it's you! Lookin' for a nitwit to buy your lunch?!
answer: Oh Norville, I --

question: Barman! Set'm up, fella!
answer: Norville, I'm sorry, I... I tried to tell you... so many times... It's hard to admit when you've been wrong. If you could just... find it in your heart to -- to give me another chance --

question: Hey! Where's that martini?!
answer: Just give me another chance, Norville -- I can help you fight this thing. I know this last story was a lie! We can prove it! We can --

question: Aww, what's the difference. I'm all washed up... When you're dead, ya stay dead... Hey, fella!
answer: Well that just about does it! I've seen Norville Barnes, the young man in a big hurry, and I've seen Norville Barnes the self-important heel, but I've never seen Norville Barnes the quitter, and I don't like it! ...Fight on, fight on, dear old Muncie. ...Fight on, hoist the gold and blue; You'll be tattered, torn and hurtin' Once 'The Munce' is done with you! Goooooo Eagles!

question: You lied to me! I can't believe you lied to me! a Muncie girl!
answer: But Norville... I... ... Oh, Norville!

question: -- Uh... Buzz, I'm sorry, I -- Buzz, you gotta forgive me! I shouldn't a fired you, I didn't know what I was doing! I was a little funny in the head, I --
answer: Aw, buddy, I don't care about that.

question: ...You don't?
answer: Nah, that's all forgotten.

question: ...It is?
answer: Sure, Mr. Muss -- uh, Sid said I could have the job back.

question: Absolutely, Buzz, I'm glad he --
answer: But he told me you stole that swell hoop idea from me. What gives!

question: But, Buzz --
answer: Say, that was a swell idea!

question: But, Buzz, you know I never --
answer: And Sid says you stole it!

question: But Buzz --
answer: Think about that, idea man!!

question: Falling.
answer: Laughing.

question: Falling, turning lazily in the air -- and suddenly, with a great moaning sound -- he stops, suspended in mid-air, head down, feet in the air.
answer: In his office, frozen with an idiotic laugh pasted to his face.

question: He gapes. Mr... Mr. Hudsucker?
answer: Ta-daaaa! ...Wooooo! ...How d'ya like this thing? They're all wearin' em upstairs now. ...It's a fad. ...Anyway. I hear you've been having, uh... ...Been having some problems with the board. The more things change, know what Iyayayeeeeee... ...Jesus Christopher -- That smarts... Where was I? Oh yeah, the board. I guess Sidney's been puttin' the screws to ya, huh, Norman?

question: Norville.
answer: Mm. Well, say what you like about the man's ethics, he's a balls-to- the-wall businessman. Beat ya any way he can. Straight for the jugular. Very effective.

question: Yes sir...
answer: Anyway. Any particular reason you didn't give him my Blue Letter? I mean, Jesus, Norman, just a dying man's last words and wishes, no big deal.

question: Huh? Oh, geez, Mr. Hudsucker, I apologize, there was an awful lot of excitement and I guess I must've mislaid --
answer: It's sittin' in your apron pocket, right where you left it. Imbecile.

question: Oh, geez.
answer: Failure to deliver a Blue Letter is grounds for dismissal.

question: Geez, I --
answer: Ah, it's New Year's, I'm not gonna add to your woes. I'm just saying.

question: Yessir.
answer: Well, why don't ya read it.

question: Sir?
answer: Yeah, go ahead. Might learn somethin'.

question: Yes sir... 'From the desk of Waring Hudsucker. To. Sidney J. Mussburger. Regarding. My demise. Dear Sid. By the time you read this, I will have joined the organization upstairs -- an exciting new beginning. I will retain fond memories of the many years you and I --
answer: Yeah, yeah, it's the standard resignation boilerplate -- go down to the second paragraph.

question: 'Many years, uh... I know that you will be wondering why I have decided to move on, ending my tenure at Hudsucker, and here on Earth. You will be thinking, Why now, when things are going so well? Granted, from the standpoint of our balance sheet and financials, sure, sure, we're doing fine. However, Sid. These things have long since ceased to give me pleasure. I look at myself now and no longer see the idealistic young man who started this company. Now I see only an empty shell whom others call a 'success.' How has this come to pass? When and why did I trade all of my hopes, dreams and aspirations, for the emptiness of power and wealth? What the heck have I done? '...Looking back now, Sid, I see that I allowed time and age to corrupt my dreams. Instead of fiercely guarding what was timeless inside of myself, I let the hubbub of earthly commerce erode my character, and dissolve my better self. How is it that some manage to preserve themselves where I have failed? Sidney, I do not know. Perhaps if others love you, you may more securely love yourself -- but I am alone. I loved a woman once, Sid, as you well know -- a beautiful, vibrant lady, an angel who in her wisdom saw fit to choose you instead of I...'
answer: Skip this part... ...Last paragraph, last paragraph.

question: '...And so, Sid, the future does not belong to such as I -- nor even you. We have made our compromises with time. The future belongs to the young, who may more energetically wage the battle against corruption. Accordingly, in the spirit of hope, and the ringing in of the new, I hereby bequeath my entire interest in the company, and my seat on the board, to whomever is Hudsucker's most recent employee at the time of my demise. I know this will disappoint you -- you, Sid, who have served so diligently and for so long. But --'
answer: -- tough titty toenails! ...That'll show the bastard! ...Yeah, go ahead.

question: '...But Sid, let me urge you to work closely with the new president, and to keep giving Hudsucker Industries all your energies -- but not your soul. For while we must strive for success, we must not worship it. Long live the Hud. Waring Hudsucker...'
answer: ...Geez. Yup. It's all there. Well, see that it gets delivered in the morning. Sheeel beeee... ...Ridin' six white horses, She'll be ridin' six white horses She'll be ridin' six white horses When she comes...

question: What the heck's he doin', Benny?
answer: What the heck's she doin', Lou?

question: What the heck they doin'?
answer: You know what they're doin' now, Lou.

question: This I know, Benny.
answer: This you're familia' with.

question: ...Geez.
answer: ...Geez.

question: ...Y'all right, Benny?
answer: ...Yeah, I'm... It's just... It's beautiful, Lou!

question: It is beautiful, Benny.
answer: ...It's the most beautiful t'ing I ever saw.

question: It's the most beautiful t'ing I ever saw.
answer: Cabbies' affair.

question: Hacks' New Year's gala. Bromo.
answer: ...Bromo.
